answers.author: Louis Smith
answers.text:
To start I believe the development of one community should "do no harm" to adjacent communities. Improving access to Matthews by making NC-74 a freeway should not decimate the economic activity(and tax base) in the neighborhoods it passes through. If it seems likely to do so then Matthews should contribute to efforts to mitigate the damage done.
Likewise, if the infrastructure of one community benefits another. That second community should share in the infrastructure cost. Thus if Mathews has a substantial number of commuters on Charlotte streets. Then Matthews should help pay for street improvements in Charlotte.

Hi Louis, 
Thank you for sharing and I hope other local government officials chime in with their personal experiences as the week goes on. On the Knowledge Network there are different documents about local governments being good neighbors to one another in many different ways. Below are a few examples of what we have on the Knowledge Network:
The Casa Grande Intergovernmental Agreement is between about the future boundaries of a few communities located near one another. icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/20875
The Community Business Attraction and Anti-Piracy Compact is another agreement between neighboring local governments. icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/304558
There are even local governments that are working together to share infrastructure from the beginning. You can read more about this in a recent blog post which also includes links to examples of collaborative service delivery agreements. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/blogs/blogpost/1583/Collaborative_Service_Delivery_A_Great_Way_to_Work_Together_and_Cut_Costs
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org
